key_facts: Globally in 2022, there were an estimated 249 million malaria cases and 608,000 malaria deaths in 85 countries.
The WHO African Region carries a disproportionately high share of the global malaria burden.
In 2022, the Region was home to 94% of malaria cases (233 million) and 95% (580,000) of malaria deaths.
Children under 5 accounted for about 80% of all malaria deaths in the Region.

overview.description: Malaria is a life-threatening disease spread to humans by some types of mosquitoes, mostly found in tropical countries. It is preventable and curable.
overview.cause: The infection is caused by a parasite and does not spread from person to person.
overview.symptoms_summary: Symptoms can be mild (fever, chills, headache) or severe (fatigue, confusion, seizures, difficulty breathing).
overview.prevention: Avoiding mosquito bites and taking medicines can prevent malaria. Treatments can stop mild cases from worsening.

transmission.main_mode: Malaria mostly spreads to people through the bites of some infected female Anopheles mosquitoes.

parasite_species.name: Plasmodium falciparum
parasite_species.description: The deadliest malaria parasite and the most prevalent on the African continent.

parasite_species.name: Plasmodium vivax
parasite_species.description: The dominant malaria parasite in most countries outside of sub-Saharan Africa.

parasite_species.name: Plasmodium malariae
parasite_species.description: One of the five species that cause malaria in humans.

severe_symptoms: Jaundice (yellowing of the eyes and skin)
symptoms.risk_of_severity: Infants, children under 5 years, pregnant women, travellers, and people with HIV or AIDS are at higher risk of severe infection.
symptoms.importance_of_testing: Because some malaria symptoms are not specific, getting tested early is important.
symptoms.effect_on_pregnancy: Malaria infection during pregnancy can cause premature delivery or delivery of a baby with low birth weight.
